shortLinksItems.hed: Beautiful, Colorful Hotels to Brighten Your Next Vacation
How to Live Like Royalty in Morocco
An Instagram Celebrity's New York City Winter Wonderland
Beautiful, Colorful Hotels to Brighten Your Next Vacation
shortLinksItems.dek: These hotels don't just integrate color into their design scheme—color *is* the design scheme. From the Pantone Hotel in Brussels to the Hotel Crayon in Paris, these hotels are sure to brighten your next vacation.
shortLinksItems.seoTitle: 8 Colorful Hotels to Brighten Your Next Vacation
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: 8 Colorful Hotels to Brighten Up Your Next Vacation

items.title: [The Saguaro](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/palm-springs/the-saguaro--palm-springs)
items.caption:
Palm Springs, California

----------

The warm hues of this hotel seem to be inspired by the desert temperatures of its Palm Springs location. The inner walls of the balconies are painted in sunset shades of red, orange, and purple, while the yellow umbrellas and deck chairs pop against the turquoise water of the Olympic-size pool they surround. Rooms at [The Saguaro](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/united-states/palm-springs/the-saguaro--palm-springs) are inspired by Mexican art and filled with hand-crafted Mexican furniture. Guests are also encouraged to peruse the art installations on rotation in the hotel's public spaces that feature work by local artists, or to get out and explore the town on one of the brightly painted cruiser bikes available.

items.title: MEININGER Hotel
items.caption:
Berlin, Germany

----------

When you think of a hotel located in an airport business park, this is probably not what you picture. Its vibrant stripped exterior is your first indication that the [MEININGER Hotel](http://www.meininger-hotels.com/en/hotels/berlin/airport/) is a far cry from the earth-toned interiors of many chain business hotels you'll find surrounding airports. The 151 rooms spread throughout its three floors are punctuated with bursts of color that pop against grey walls and white bedding. Common areas like the lounge are filled with royal blue sofas, while colorful murals of landscape photography occupy the walls of the bar and guest kitchen.

items.title: Inntel Hotels Amsterdam Zaandam
items.caption:
Zaandam, Netherlands

----------

 The facades of nearly 70 individual houses were combined to make the [Inntel Hotels Amsterdam Zaandam](http://www.inntelhotelsamsterdamzaandam.nl/en/Home.html). The architecture is inspired by the traditional houses and colors found around the Zaan region, featuring green gables trimmed in white. The hotel's 160 rooms feature relics from the Zaan region's culture and history. While this hotel wears its color on its sleeve, the rooms are far from monochromatic. Murals featuring black and white photography are paired with brightly colored chairs and the Taste Delux room features floor-to-ceiling colored images of vintage advertisements.

items.title: Inn at John O'Groats
items.caption:
John O’Groats, Scotland

----------


This hotel is a burst of color protruding from the dramatic coastline of Scotland's Northern Highlands. It was originally built in 1875 and recently underwent a [renovation and reopening](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-09-22/new-inn-at-john-o-groats-scotland) that saw the addition of several Nordic-style dwellings. The red, yellow, blue, green, and tan facades look all the more vibrant standing in a row beside the white structure that served as the original hotel. The [Inn at John O'Groats](https://www.naturalretreats.com/uk/destinations/scotland/john-ogroats/) has 17 rooms, all of which feature locally-sourced art, including a penthouse apartment inside the turret of the main building, which offers 180 degree views of the coast.
items.credit: *Photo courtesy the Inn at John O'Groats*

items.title: Hotel Crayon
items.caption:
Paris, France

----------

With a name like [Hotel Crayon](http://www.hotelcrayon.com/), you'd expect this Paris accommodation to deliver a Crayola box-worth of colors. The hotel, a short distance from the Louvre, was designed by artist Julie Gauthron and features her artwork throughout. The rooms in this "bohemian chic" hotel are filled with vibrant vintage and modern pieces of furniture and feature walls coated in purples, blues, and greens. One room even has coloring book-style wallpaper that Gauthron's daughter helped fill in portions of. Gauthron also designed the equally colorful [Crayon Rouge](http://www.hotelcrayonrouge.com/hotel.html), a "little brother" hotel to the Hotel Crayon. Both are located in the 1st arrondissement.

items.title: Pantone Hotel
items.caption:
Brussels, Belgium

----------

Color-matching and trend forecasting company Pantone Inc. opened [a hotel](http://www.pantonehotel.com/) in Brussels in 2010. The 59-room boutique hotel was designed by Olivier Hannaert and Michel Penneman in a renovated 1970s low-rise. Each of the seven floors are designated a different color, and rooms feature giant Pantone color swatches that hang as artwork on the walls. The hotel offers guests full color immersion during their stay: Sip coffee from a Pantone mug over the hotel's buffet breakfast, then hop on a Pantone bike and head out to explore Brussels.

items.title: Semiramis
items.caption:
Athens, Greece

----------

This hotel is an ode to modern art. It's the creation of Karim Rashid, an interior architect and industrial designer, and art collector Dakis Joannou. By day, sun umbrellas and the patterned tiles of the hotel pool bathe the patio in green, blue, and pink. By night, the hotel's facade is illuminated in lime green and orange. The 52 rooms are blanketed in color and feature light-box art installations above the beds and translucent furniture in vibrant hues. Public areas at the [Semiramis](http://semiramis.athenshotels.it/) are equally colorful and eclectic and house gallery space for art exhibitions.

items.title: Hotel Zed
items.caption:
Victoria, British Columbia

----------

[Hotel Zed](http://www.hotelzed.com/), a self-described "ridiculously fun hotel," features psychedelic colors and design details. It's a mix of vintage and ultramodern: Bedside tables are decorated with working vintage rotary phones, but include QR code instructions on how to use them. The lobby features typewriters ready for writing home, a high-tech media hub with Wii and Wi-Fi, and a vinyl-record listening station. And the color doesn't end at the hotel: They shuttle guests to and from town (only a five-minute drive) in a restored 1967 Volkswagen bus.

shortLinksItems.seoDescription: These hotels don't just integrate color into their design scheme—color is the design scheme. From the Pantone Hotel in Brussels to the Hotel Crayon in Paris, these seven hotels are sure to brighten your next vacation.
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: These hotels don't just integrate color into their design scheme—color is the design scheme. From the Pantone Hotel in Brussels to the Hotel Crayon in Paris, these seven hotels are sure to brighten your next vacation.

fields.name: Lauren Kilberg
fields.shortBio: Collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.
fields.bio: Lauren Kilberg is a freelance writer and blogger residing in Chicago. Her travels have found her camping near the Pakistani border of India, conquering volcanoes in the Philippines and being humbled in Haiti. She spent two years living and working in South Korea before repatriating to the United States, but not before taking the six-month scenic route home via a backpacking trip from Indonesia to India. In short, she's a collector of maps, passport stamps, and freckles.

shortLinksItems.hed: How to Live Like Royalty in Morocco
shortLinksItems.dek: In exotic Morocco, why choose a staid hotel when you can stay like a sultan? Peek inside a palace oasis in the Palmeraie, a riad that belonged to the pasha of Marrakech, or a high-class home turned hotel in Fez—all where the royal treatment reigns.

items.caption: Ever wanted to rule your own kingdom? At [Palais Namaskar] (http://www.palaisnamaskar.com) you can—for a night, at least. This sanctuary, located in the desert-and-palm-grove Palmeraie region about 25 minutes from Marrakech, boasts three large private palaces within its 12-acre compound. The front terrace of the gold-domed Pool Palace is shown here; its lagoon-filled layout includes multiple bedrooms, each with a plunge pool, and a grand private pool. A 24-hour butler is on hand to attend to every command, too.

Long walkways float over tranquil blue reflecting pools, connecting the rooms and palaces of the resort. A riot of palms, olive trees, flowering bushes, and fruit trees (like ripe pomegranates you can pull straight from branch) line the waters, with Moorish-style archways following alongside. And if you prefer not to walk the expansive grounds, a personal “carriage” (golf cart) can be arranged to zip you around the resort.

Even if you choose not to stay in one of Palais Namaskar’s three palace complexes, all of the resort's rooms are quite regal—and focused around water. Draw the sheer drapes around your personal heated swimming pool for extra privacy, or sprawl in an outdoor day bed, lazily gazing across the neighboring courtyards and waterways.

To counter the assault of colors, sounds, and smells that greet visitors to the famous Marrakech medina, Palais Namaskar’s designers opted for a subdued touch. A palette of chocolates, tans, and whites, plus a thoughtful set-up that nods to feng shui principles, resulted in this calming sanctuary.

Fragrant blooms like bougainvillea, plumbago, and oleander drape the resort’s archways, but the top note in the air is Arabian jasmine—as if the grounds are “naturally perfumed with Chanel No. 5,” according to general manager Laurent Branover.

Decadent breakfasts at Le Namaskar restaurant always begin with an artful display of fresh fruit. For other meals, guests can choose between two additional on-site restaurants, serving French, Thai, and Moroccan dishes. At night, the resort’s No Mad Bar boasts a stunning view of the Palmeraie oasis that stretches all the way to the Atlas mountains. And afterward—so long as your pocketbook rivals that of a king—you can take your leave in style on the resort’s private jet.

There’s no shortage of storied accommodation in Marrakech, but [Riad Star’s](http://www.marrakech-riad.co.uk/riad-star-homepage/) rich history packs a double-punch. It has a royal pedigree (the 17th-century building was a part of the palace complex), and once housed pioneering dance superstar Josephine Baker. The American-born artist, who rose to prominence in 1920s Paris, lived in the riad in the early 1940s as the guest—and assumed lover—of the pasha of Marrakech, Thami El Glaoui.

Riad Star’s owners, Mike and Lucie Wood, learned of the building’s star-studded history from neighbors through casual conversation. This suite, “The Josephine,” has an additional secret: The street-facing window is rumored to have been the spot where the Pasha paid local children to read verses of the Q’uran to an ailing Baker.

“We wanted to bring Josephine Baker back to life,” says owner Lucie Wood. To do so, the Woods outfitted the hotel as a mini-museum to the Jazz Age performer. Memorabilia like books, albums, posters, even clothing are tastefully arranged throughout, and larger-than-life photographs of Baker are projected onto the walls at night.

Slip into the role of a silver screen queen yourself with the riad’s collection of ’20s-style clothing, including two of Josephine Baker’s original sequined stage costumes. Flapper dresses, fancy headpieces, boas, bags, and more are available for guests to pillage, turning a stay here into a glamorous affair. A large collection of locally-made pierced-metal filigree lamps fling sparkles around the riad and set the mood.

A belly-dancer glides across the floor, sweeping a golden scarf, beneath the projected image of Baker. In addition to private shows, Riad Star also occasionally covers the courtyard pool to devote space to yoga classes, large dinner parties, and other special events.

items.title: Riad Idrissy in Fez, A High-Class Home Turned Hotel
items.caption: Marrakech’s medina has long been considered a hotbed for restored riads, but Fez, the country’s third largest city, is rapidly catching up. In the midst of the Fez medina’s 9,500-some streets stands posh [Riad Idrissy] (http://www.riadidrissy.com/), the result of a six-year renovation of the Idrissy family’s 400-year-old home. In addition to the riad’s classic patterned wooden doors, intricate plaster carving, and restored Fassi architecture are sumptuous touches like heated towel rods and anti-fog mirrors—perfect for contemporary royalty.

Stately and ornate, Riad Idrissy’s hand-painted doors are one of the centerpieces of the open, triple-story courtyard. The doors open in multiple ways—those inner, arched frames swing out too—which helps to regulate heating and cooling in each salon.

One of the two ground-level salons of Riad Idrissy has been turned into a comfortable guest room, complete with a combination of Moroccan/African furnishings. The other remains a common area, lined with couches and tables.

Complimentary caftans are available to don within the riad; tea, hot coffee, tea, and treats are left outside your door each morning; and earplugs are offered lest the evening prayer call disturbs your sleep. Plus, a luxurious rooftop hammam (a steamy bath with head-to-toe exfoliation) elevates the traditional public bathhouse ritual with private treatments and massages.

Riad Idrissy extends into an open, plant-filled oasis—also known as its restaurant, Ruined Garden. Set in the footprint of the grand riad that stood next to the Idrissy family, it took five donkeys five months, load by load, to clear enough rubble to reveal the foundation and original tile floors. British co-owner Robert Johnstone has slowly transformed the space into a leafy getaway with just the right hint of wildness. Guests at the riad take their breakfast here.

Ruined Garden is dotted with a mishmash of antique tables and chairs tucked into the old riad’s salons, plus decorative touches like straw hats, an *eza fa* (traditional long broom) turned into a trellis, and other found objects. Some of the walls of the original home were left intact, keeping its rich history very much alive.

Tajines, local vegetables, and Mediterranean flavors make the Ruined Garden a destination for foos-lovers. The only catch: Since it’s located within the walled medina, Fez’s religious center, no alcohol is served. But if you’re a riad guest, simply take an after-dinner glass of wine back to your room (where it’s permitted)—and perhaps some of the house chocolate mousse, too. If you’re a non-guest, you can take advantage of a different royal treatment: having a porter escort you to and from the restaurant to your hotel, free of charge.

*All photos by Tanveer Badal*

shortLinksItems.seoTitle: How to Live Like Royalty in Morocco
shortLinksItems.seoDescription: Peek inside a palace oasis in the Palmeraie, a riad that belonged to the pasha of Marrakech, or a high-class home turned hotel in Fez—all where the royal treatment reigns.
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: 18 Places Where You Can Travel Like Royalty in Morocco
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: Peek inside a palace oasis in the Palmeraie, a riad that belonged to the pasha of Marrakech, or a high-class home turned hotel in Fez—all where the royal treatment reigns.

fields.name: Kelly Phillips Badal
fields.shortBio: Kelly Phillips Badal is a NYC-based magazine writer and editor with a passion for travel, food, culture, and design.
fields.bio:
Kelly Phillips Badal is a NYC-based writer and magazine editor with almost a decade of experience, specializing in lifestyle, travel, and home design. She's held staff positions at *Better Homes & Gardens* and Country Living magazine; her work has also appeared in *Seventeen, Teen People*, CNTraveler.com, CoolHunting.com, and Fitnessmagazine.com. 

Currently Kelly is in the midst of traveling the world for all of the 2014 year, while documenting her adventures for various publications. Her home remains New York City, where she lives with her husband Tanveer, a photographer and frequent collaborator.

shortLinksItems.hed: An Instagram Celebrity's New York City Winter Wonderland
shortLinksItems.dek: Although New York City is getting its share of snow this winter, it's not as intense as the polar vortex the city experienced in winter 2013. Here are some memorable photographs from that snowy, icy season, as seen by Instagram photo celebrity [@kat_in_nyc](http://instagram.com/kat_in_nyc/).
shortLinksItems.seoTitle: An Instagram Celebrity's New York City Winter Wonderland
shortLinksItems.socialTitle: 14 Photos Of New York City That Will Make You Shiver

items.caption: Snow didn't deter pedestrians from walking around in Lower Manhattan.
Although Central Park is known for its grassy lawns, it's still eerily beautiful in the cold.
Despite the cold, there are still signs of life and vibrancy.
The white skies put New York's bridges into relief.
Here's the view from beneath the Manhattan Bridge.
... and here's that same view with a flower, giving a hint of the spring that will eventually come.
Stone Street in Lower Manhattan has a quiet, peaceful feel.
The Financial District never sleeps, even when it's freezing out.
This woman heads to the iconic [Delmonico's Steakhouse](http://www.delmonicosrestaurantgroup.com/restaurant/), which calls itself "America's first fine dining restaurant," with an umbrella in tow.
The snow and sleet still couldn't keep New York's intrepid taxi drivers off of the roads.
Central Park... or a set from the movie *Maleficent*?
Even on a snowy afternoon, Central Park still provides a calm oasis in the center of the bustling city.
This shot captures the Dumbo neighborhood in Brooklyn, which has spectacular views (like this one) of the Manhattan Bridge.
On the coldest days, wind swirled the snowflakes and made a winter wonderland.

shortLinksItems.seoDescription: Although New York City is getting its share of snow this winter, it's not as intense as the polar vortex the city experienced in winter 2013. Here are some memorable photographs from that snowy, icy season.
shortLinksItems.socialDescription: Although New York City is getting its share of snow this winter, it's not as intense as the polar vortex the city experienced in winter 2013. Here are some memorable photographs from that snowy, icy season.

featureContentItems.hed: Beautiful, Colorful Hotels to Brighten Your Next Vacation
featureContentItems.dek: These hotels don't just integrate color into their design scheme—color *is* the design scheme. From the Pantone Hotel in Brussels to the Hotel Crayon in Paris, these hotels are sure to brighten your next vacation.
featureContentItems.seoTitle: 8 Colorful Hotels to Brighten Your Next Vacation
featureContentItems.socialTitle: 8 Colorful Hotels to Brighten Up Your Next Vacation

In the midst of the Fez medina’s 9,500-some streets stands posh [Riad Idrissy] (http://www.riadidrissy.com/), the result of a six-year renovation of the Idrissy family’s 400-year-old home. In addition to the riad’s classic patterned wooden doors, intricate plaster carving, and restored Fassi architecture are sumptuous touches like heated towel rods and anti-fog mirrors—perfect for contemporary royalty.

Stately and ornate, Riad Idrissy’s hand-painted doors are one of the centerpieces of the open, triple-story courtyard. The doors open in multiple ways—those inner, arched frames swing out too—which helps to regulate heating and cooling in each salon.

One of the two ground-level salons of Riad Idrissy has been turned into a comfortable guest room, complete with a combination of Moroccan/African furnishings. The other remains a common area, lined with couches and tables.

Complimentary caftans are available to don within the riad; tea, hot coffee, tea, and treats are left outside your door each morning; and earplugs are offered lest the evening prayer call disturbs your sleep. Plus, a luxurious rooftop hammam (a steamy bath with head-to-toe exfoliation) elevates the traditional public bathhouse ritual with private treatments and massages.

Riad Idrissy extends into an open, plant-filled oasis—also known as its restaurant, Ruined Garden. Set in the footprint of the grand riad that stood next to the Idrissy family, it took five donkeys five months, load by load, to clear enough rubble to reveal the foundation and original tile floors. British co-owner Robert Johnstone has slowly transformed the space into a leafy getaway with just the right hint of wildness. Guests at the riad take their breakfast here.

Ruined Garden is dotted with a mishmash of antique tables and chairs tucked into the old riad’s salons, plus decorative touches like straw hats, an *eza fa* (traditional long broom) turned into a trellis, and other found objects. Some of the walls of the original home were left intact, keeping its rich history very much alive.

Tajines, local vegetables, and Mediterranean flavors make the Ruined Garden a destination for foos-lovers. The only catch: Since it’s located within the walled medina, Fez’s religious center, no alcohol is served. But if you’re a riad guest, simply take an after-dinner glass of wine back to your room (where it’s permitted)—and perhaps some of the house chocolate mousse, too. If you’re a non-guest, you can take advantage of a different royal treatment: having a porter escort you to and from the restaurant to your hotel, free of charge.

*All photos by Tanveer Badal*

featureContentItems.seoTitle: How to Live Like Royalty in Morocco
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Peek inside a palace oasis in the Palmeraie, a riad that belonged to the pasha of Marrakech, or a high-class home turned hotel in Fez—all where the royal treatment reigns.
featureContentItems.socialTitle: 18 Places Where You Can Travel Like Royalty in Morocco
featureContentItems.socialDescription: Peek inside a palace oasis in the Palmeraie, a riad that belonged to the pasha of Marrakech, or a high-class home turned hotel in Fez—all where the royal treatment reigns.

fields.name: Kelly Phillips Badal
fields.shortBio: Kelly Phillips Badal is a NYC-based magazine writer and editor with a passion for travel, food, culture, and design.
fields.bio:
Kelly Phillips Badal is a NYC-based writer and magazine editor with almost a decade of experience, specializing in lifestyle, travel, and home design. She's held staff positions at *Better Homes & Gardens* and Country Living magazine; her work has also appeared in *Seventeen, Teen People*, CNTraveler.com, CoolHunting.com, and Fitnessmagazine.com. 

Currently Kelly is in the midst of traveling the world for all of the 2014 year, while documenting her adventures for various publications. Her home remains New York City, where she lives with her husband Tanveer, a photographer and frequent collaborator.

featureContentItems.hed: An Instagram Celebrity's New York City Winter Wonderland
featureContentItems.dek: Although New York City is getting its share of snow this winter, it's not as intense as the polar vortex the city experienced in winter 2013. Here are some memorable photographs from that snowy, icy season, as seen by Instagram photo celebrity [@kat_in_nyc](http://instagram.com/kat_in_nyc/).
featureContentItems.seoTitle: An Instagram Celebrity's New York City Winter Wonderland
featureContentItems.socialTitle: 14 Photos Of New York City That Will Make You Shiver

items.caption: Snow didn't deter pedestrians from walking around in Lower Manhattan.
Although Central Park is known for its grassy lawns, it's still eerily beautiful in the cold.
Despite the cold, there are still signs of life and vibrancy.
The white skies put New York's bridges into relief.
Here's the view from beneath the Manhattan Bridge.
... and here's that same view with a flower, giving a hint of the spring that will eventually come.
Stone Street in Lower Manhattan has a quiet, peaceful feel.
The Financial District never sleeps, even when it's freezing out.
This woman heads to the iconic [Delmonico's Steakhouse](http://www.delmonicosrestaurantgroup.com/restaurant/), which calls itself "America's first fine dining restaurant," with an umbrella in tow.
The snow and sleet still couldn't keep New York's intrepid taxi drivers off of the roads.
Central Park... or a set from the movie *Maleficent*?
Even on a snowy afternoon, Central Park still provides a calm oasis in the center of the bustling city.
This shot captures the Dumbo neighborhood in Brooklyn, which has spectacular views (like this one) of the Manhattan Bridge.
On the coldest days, wind swirled the snowflakes and made a winter wonderland.

featureContentItems.hed: 10 Romantic Traditions Around the World (That Aren't Valentine's Day)
featureContentItems.dek: While Valentine's Day is now celebrated in many countries around the world, the holiday isn't the only, or even the oldest, devoted to a day of love. From China to Romania, here are 10 traditions that have nothing to do with St. Valentine.

items.title: China: Qixi Festival
items.caption: China has not one, but two versions of Valentine's Day. The Qixi Festival goes back some 2,000 years and still survives outside of major cities. It falls on the seventh day of the seventh month on the lunar calendar (this year, August 20). Its origins spun out of an ancient Chinese folk tale called "The Weaver Girl and the Cowherd," in which a fairy (the weaver girl) falls for a mortal (the cowherd), which angers her mother, who just happens to be the goddess of heaven. Her mother separates them, but the pair are eventually allowed to reunite once a year on—you guessed it—the seventh day of the seventh month.

Surviving customs are mostly related to weaving, such as needlework competitions, but other practices include mass weddings and wearing traditional clothes from the Han Dynasty. In some places, young single women also pray for a husband during the "Begging for Cleverness" ceremony (pictured).

items.title: Hong Kong: Lantern Festival
items.caption: This event is celebrated on the 15th day of the lunar calendar (this year, March 5). While its origins are disputed, most believe that matchmaking was once an important aspect since single people were among those who carried lit lanterns through the streets at night. Today the Lantern Festival marks the end of the Chinese New Year, but it's still embraced as a day of love. In fact, one of the traditions is for couples to visit a temple and pray to "Yue Lao," the mythological god of marriage and love.

items.title: Romania: Dragobete
items.caption: Dragobete was the god of love back in Pagan times, when the holiday started as a celebration of spring. According to one folk tale, boys and girls would spend the day in the woods gathering flowers, and then the girls would run home at sunset. Boys would chase the girl they liked, and simply catching and kissing her would announce their engagement to the village. While that custom has long fallen out of practice, Dragobete is still considered the original Romanian Valentine's Day and celebrated on February 24.

items.title: Slovenia: St. Gregory’s Day
items.caption: In Slovenia, March 12 signified the start of spring and all things related to love. The latter is still observed on what's also called Gregorjevo, and there's a popular Slovenian saying that birds get married on this day. One of the event's long-standing traditions has been to give heart-shaped honey cookies to loved ones. (Bird decor is also prominently featured.)

items.title: Saint Jordi's Day, Spain
items.caption:
Saint Jordi's Day, (also known as Saint George's Day), dates back to Roman times, when Saint Jordi was believed to have been a Roman soldier who became a Christian martyr. The actual reasons behind the day are murky, but time has turned his actual story into a (familiar) tale of a hero who slayed a dragon in order to save a princess. 

St. Jordi's Day is especially popular in Barcelona and the Catalonia region, and celebrated on April 23. The tradition of men giving women roses is believed to have started in the middle ages, but in more recent times women also give men books for an interesting twist. The origins of the latter are less murky (and fanciful), but sprung out of the fact that since William Shakespeare also died on Apr. 23, the traditions of rose and book giving were combined.

items.title: Wales: St. Dwynwen's Day
items.caption: January 25 marks the Welsh celebration for St. Dwynwen, considered the patron saint of lovers. Allegedly, Dwynwen fell in love with a man she couldn’t marry since she was already engaged. She was so upset that they couldn’t be together that she went to the other extreme and founded a convent. The ruins of her church still stand on Llanddwyn Island, off the coast of North Wales. To mark the occasion, some intrepid couples make a pilgrimage to the church, while others give a traditional Welsh [love spoon](http://www.cadwyngifts.com/welshlovespoons-c-65.html) as a token of endearment.

items.title: Brazil: Dia dos Namorados
items.caption: Also known as Lover’s Day, this Brazilian holiday is celebrated the same way as Valentine's Day, just on a different date. It's supposedly observed on June 12 since it falls on the eve of St. Anthony's Day—he's the patron saint of marriage. Other theories suggest that it's celebrated in June so that it doesn't overlap with Carnival, although that didn't stop couples from celebrating the event when it overlapped with last year's World Cup.

items.title: South Korea: White Day
items.caption: In South Korea women give men chocolate on Valentine's Day, so men return the favor on March 14, also known as White Day. The holiday is also observed in China and Japan, but South Korea takes it to the next level by tossing friends, family, and coworkers into the mix.

items.title: Israel: Tu B'Av
items.caption: Although Tu B'Av is a minor Jewish holiday, you'd never know it by the way some couples embrace is. Israel's original holiday of love dates back to biblical times, when single women would wear white and dance in vineyards at the start of the grape harvest season. Today, Tu B'Av (which typically happens during the summer) is more likely to be celebrated like Valentine's, with chocolate and flowers instead of with vineyard dancing.

items.title: Finland: Friend’s Day
items.caption: Not every tradition is all about romantic love—good news for the unattached who dread Valentine's. Friend’s Day, or Ystävänpäivä in Finnish, is also observed on February 14, but with a twist. Back in the '80s the country decided to change the nature of the holiday to be more inclusive, and so Friend's Day was born. It's really the best of both worlds: Since it's still customary to give cards, candy, and flowers (pink roses instead of the romantic red are the norm), nobody feels left out. Warm fuzzies for all!

featureContentItems.seoTitle: 10 Romantic Traditions Around the World (That Aren't Valentine's Day)
featureContentItems.seoDescription: While Valentine's Day is now celebrated in many countries around the world, the holiday isn't the only, or even the oldest, devoted to a day of love. From China to Romania, here are 10 traditions that have nothing to do with St. Valentine.

fields.name: Meredith Rosenberg
fields.shortBio: Meredith Rosenberg is a contributing web producer at *Architectural Digest.*
fields.bio: [Meredith Rosenberg](meredithlrosenberg.com) is a contributing web producer and writer at *Architectural Digest.* She’s spent the past decade as a writer and editor, and most recently produced videos for *The Village Voice.* Her travels have taken her from Alaska to Morocco, with India next in her sights. In her downtime she practices as much yoga as possible and fantasizes about yoga (and non-yoga) vacations. She graduated from the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism.

featureContentItems.hed: Italian Port Towns Untouched By Tourists
featureContentItems.dek: Everyone knows (and loves) Positano, Portofino, and the Cinque Terre. But Italy’s home to many lesser-known port towns that are just as beautiful—and free of tourists.

items.title: PORTO VENERE
items.caption: The small fishing village of Porto Venere is just a short boat ride away from the famous towns of the Cinque Terre and shares all of its beauty and charms—without the gawking tourists. The port itself is picturesque, but we encourage you to delve a little deeper into the rustic village. You’ll find spectacular ancient ruins, beautiful churches, and even a sprawling ancient castle with panoramic views over the town and the turquoise-hued Ligurian sea.

items.title: PIOMBINO
items.caption: Formerly a naval base, the stunning port of Piombino is now primarily used for freight transport and as a marina. Legend has it that Napoleon Bonaparte once gifted the beautiful seaside town to his sister, who quickly dubbed it “Little Paris.” It’s not hard to see why: Piombino is filled with extravagant architecture, fountains, museums, and other cultural attractions. We recommend hiking up the sea cliff to Piazza Bovio, where you can enjoy views of the harbor and all the way to Elba Island—home to some of [Italy’s prettiest secret beaches](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/07/skip-capri-go-here-instead).

items.title: PORTO SANTO STEFANO
items.caption: This gorgeous Tuscan port town—just minutes away from [L’Argentario](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/07/skip-capri-go-here-instead) and a quick ferry ride to Giglio Island—features a must-see ancient fortress that was built under Spanish rule in the 17th century. It’s also home to two Spanish lookout towers from the same time period, which offer unbeatable vistas of the port. More a foodie than a history buff? Not to worry—Porto Santo Stefano is known for having the freshest seafood around, as well as some top-notch Tuscan ristorantes.

items.title: PONZA
items.caption: The pretty town of Ponza is home to a large, sheltered fishing and boating port flanked by restaurants, boutiques, bakeries, and cafes. Though the town bustles with activity, Ponza still manages to remain relatively uncrowded and free of foreign visitors (the majority come from Rome, which is only two hours away). We encourage you to venture from the busy port and discover Ponza’s gorgeous swimming grottoes and its popular moon-shaped bay, Chiaia di Luna—easily one of Italy’s most stunning beaches.

items.title: TROPEA
items.caption: Tropea was built as a commercial port during the Roman Empire (legend has it that Hercules claimed it as his own during his quest for the golden fleece). Hercules had good taste: With soaring cliffs, exquisite architecture, and pristine white sand beaches, we’d want to lay claim to Tropea, too. The walled town center is dense with cute boutiques, cozy trattorias, and gelaterias—but surprisingly, almost no tourists besides other Italians on holiday.

items.title: CAMOGLI
items.caption: Okay, so we’ve already waxed lyrical about [Camogli, one of Italy’s best-kept secrets](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/02/camogli-italy-hidden-riviera). So why aren’t you there already, sipping a glass of prosecco and watching the sun set over the Italian Riviera? The sleepy, colorful port town still remains the summer getaway of choice by wealthy Milanese and Turinese, but it doesn’t mean that you can’t enjoy the luxe life, too—if only temporarily. Unlike the narrow, tourist-congested streets of nearby Portofino, Camogli has quiet, open piazzas and nature paths that will lead you up to some spectacular coastal views.

items.title: SAN REMO
items.caption: With its pretty seaside promenades, Belle Époque hotels, and art nouveau casino, the port town of San Remo isn’t exactly a secret anymore—but it still hides in the shadow of nearby Portofino. Why go here instead? The area has an old-world grandeur about it, with sandy shores that are significantly less crowded and the fitting nickname “La Cittá dei Fiori” (the City of Flowers).

items.title: GAETA
items.caption: Set between Rome and Naples, the gorgeous town of Gaeta is set on a promontory overlooking (not surprisingly) the Gulf of Gaeta. The town, primarily a fishing and oil seaport, features the typical pastel-colored cliff houses, narrow alleys, medieval churches, and even a 13th-century castle. There are some stretches of public beach available away from the busy deep-water ports, but the main draw here is Montagna Spaccata—a mountain supposedly split in half by an earthquake.

featureContentItems.seoTitle: Italian Port Towns Untouched By Tourists
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Everyone knows (and loves) Positano, Portofino, and the Cinque Terre. But Italy’s home to many lesser-known port towns that are just as beautiful—and free of tourists.

Hercules had good taste: With soaring cliffs, exquisite architecture, and pristine white sand beaches, we’d want to lay claim to Tropea, too. The walled town center is dense with cute boutiques, cozy trattorias, and gelaterias—but surprisingly, almost no tourists besides other Italians on holiday.

fields.name: Krisanne Fordham
fields.shortBio: Krisanne Fordham is a contributing editor at *Condé Nast Traveler*
fields.bio: Krisanne Fordham is a contributing digital editor at *Condé Nast Traveler* and a writer for CNN Travel, *Departures* and *Travel + Leisure.* Previously, she was a staff editor at *Condé Nast Traveler* and The AOL-Huffington Post Media Group. Krisanne grew up in Sydney, Australia and splits her time between New York and Italy.

featureContentItems.hed: 10 Best Free Things to Do in Dublin
featureContentItems.dek: Dublin is full of attractions with steep price tags. Luckily, the city also has a range of free options that will give visitors an even better dose of the history and culture of the city. With free admission to all the national museums and even a free tour of the President’s house, you’ll have Dublin covered before you even reach for your wallet.

items.title: National Museums
items.caption: [All of the government-run museums](http://www.museum.ie/en/homepage.aspx) in Dublin are free and open to the public. Try the National Museum for Natural History, also known by locals as the “Dead Zoo” because of the many taxidermied creatures that live on in the old building. The National Museum for Archaeology has an exhibit on mummified people who were found throughout the country in peat bogs, and the National Museum for the Decorative Arts has an exhibit called "What We Wore," featuring Irish clothing through the ages. These museums are closed on Mondays and national holidays.

items.title: Chester Beatty Library
items.caption: More of a museum than a library, the [Chester Beatty Library](http://www.cbl.ie/) holds a collection of artifacts and antiquities donated to the city of Dublin by mining magnate Sir Alfred Chester Beatty. The library holds original illustrated copies of the Qur’an and the Bible, and the exhibit on the Art of the Book gives you an in-depth look at the way the written word developed in various cultures over centuries. Make sure to take the stairs all the way up to the rooftop meditation garden to look out over the city.

items.title: The Science Gallery
items.caption: [The Science Gallery](https://dublin.sciencegallery.com/), set just inside the gates of Trinity College, combines the nerdiness of science with the cool factor of an art gallery. You’ll find exhibits focusing on the science of desire and risk, blood, or surface tension. Manned by helpful Trinity College post-graduate students, the exhibits aim to push visitors to ask questions and spark discussions about how the theories of science intersect with our lives on a daily basis.

items.title: City Parks
items.caption: Dublin’s well-manicured city parks provide peaceful escapes in the midst of busy city streets and sidewalks. The buzziest one is St. Stephen’s Green at the top of Grafton Street, where you can watch the swan family in the pond. For the best picnic, try Merrion Square on a Thursday at lunchtime for the local food stalls. And for real peace and quiet, visit the Iveagh Gardens, where you might be the only non-local. The city parks close at dusk, so keep an ear out for the ringing bell that alerts visitors to the closing iron gates.

items.title: Trinity College
items.caption: Trinity College sits on over forty acres of space in the center of Dublin city, surrounded on all sides by high wrought iron fencing. As soon as you enter through the giant wooden door, the city noises fade away. You can take a guided (paid) tour hosted by Trinity College history majors, or simply wander your way through the grounds, visiting the campus art gallery and even catching a cricket match on a Sunday afternoon.

items.title: Tour the President’s House
items.caption: You can tour [Aras an Uachtarain](http://www.heritageireland.ie/en/Dublin/ArasanUachtarain/) (pronounced *are-as an uck-tah-rahn*), the residence of the President of Ireland. Tucked into Dublin’s largest park, [Phoenix Park](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-11-14/phoenix-park-the-prettiest-spot-in-dublin), Aras An Uachtarain was built in 1751 as the more modest home of the Phoenix Park ranger. After several renovations and extensions, the grand white building now resembles America’s White House. Visit the Phoenix Park Visitors Centre for tickets, which are on a first-come, first-served basis.

items.title: Galleries
items.caption: In addition to the national museums, Dublin has a selection of galleries, both large and small. The Hugh Lane Gallery, next to the (also free) Garden of Remembrance, has Francis Bacon’s entire London studio set up in the back. The Royal Hibernian Academy Gallery has a two-month-long annual exhibit each summer that is full of amateur and acclaimed artists. The National Gallery of Ireland has short tours several times each day to introduce visitors to their permanent collection.

items.title: Temple Bar Food Market
items.caption: Each Saturday, Meetinghouse Square in Temple Bar transforms into a [farmer’s market](http://www.templebar.ie/markets/article/temple-bar-food-market) with stalls full of produce, cheese, baked goods, olives, and even oysters. Meetinghouse Square happens to have a beautiful permanent umbrellas overhead, making it a great destination even on soggy days. Tip: visit the Llewellyn’s Orchard stall for hot cider with a shot of Irish whiskey that’s warming even on the dreariest of days.

items.title: Buskers on Grafton Street
items.caption: You can probably skip the shopping scene on Grafton Street (which is filled with chains you'll find in the U.S.); but the buskers are reason enough to stroll down the wide pedestrian street. A classically trained pianist regularly rolls his full-size piano down the street from the tram line, while a novice fire-breathing magician often takes up residence at the top of the street and looks for audience help with his straitjacket unicycling. And around the holidays, you might even find [Bono himself out with Glen Hansard]( http://www.irishcentral.com/news/u2s-bono-busks-on-dublins-famed-grafton-street-christmas-eve-2013-video-237292721-237793631.html).

items.title: Georgian Doors
items.caption: No matter where you are in Dublin, you aren’t very far from rows of those postcard-perfect Georgian doors. Stroll Henrietta Street on the north side of the city or Merrion Square on the south side of the city, and marvel at the paint colors, intricate door-knockers, and boot-scrapers. Remnants from the 1700s, when Dublin was the largest and most prosperous city in the British Empire after London, the Georgian homes were built with red brick facades and stunning ceiling plasterwork. To get a glimpse of what a Georgian home would have looked like in the time they were built, visit [Number 29 Georgian Museum](http://www.esb.ie/main/about-esb/numbertwentynine/default.htm) (entrance fee applies).

featureContentItems.seoTitle: 10 Best Free Things to Do in Dublin
featureContentItems.seoDescription: Dublin is full of attractions with steep price tags. Luckily, the city also has a range of free options that will give visitors an even better dose of the history and culture of the city.

fields.name: Emily Westbrooks
fields.shortBio: Emily Westbrooks is a Dublin-based writer, founder of [From China Village,](http://www.fromchinavillage.com/) and author of [Delightful Dublin](http://www.delightfuldublin.com/), an e-guide to her adopted city.
fields.bio: Emily Westbrooks is a Dublin-based freelance writer and blogger, passionately sharing her tips for getting the best of Dublin on her lifestyle, design, and travel blog [From China Village](http://www.fromchinavillage.com/). She is the author of a beautiful and useful travel guide to her adopted home, called [Delightful Dublin](http://www.delightfuldublin.com/). If you find her in Dublin, she's likely sipping a coffee in a cafe with her husband and daydreaming about her next adventure.

featureContentItems.dek: Whether you're traveling for work, or just want to be treated like a CEO, book a seat in the premium classes of these 20 airlines—our readers' favorites for business travel. [View the complete 2013 Business Travel Awards](http://cntraveler.com/travel-tips/business-travel/polls/2013/best-business-travel-hotels-airlines.html).
featureContentItems.hed: The Best Airlines for Business Travelers

items.title: Virgin America
items.caption: Ranked the best in ticketing, Web site, cabin comfort, service, entertainment, and food/beverage, it's not surprise that Virgin America is the domestic business traveler's top choice. One reader was "pleasantly surprised" by the airline's "new planes and the gracious service." "Flight attendants are nice and they cater to every clientele," says another.

items.title: Sun Country Airlines
items.caption: Travelers are "impressed" with Sun Country's customer service, giving the airline a score an 87.9 for service. "They are our new #1 consideration for flying," says one happy customer. Boarding was "seamless and easy," but some travelers say the seats are "a little too crowded."

items.title: Hawaiian Airlines
items.caption: Hawaiian Airline's "amazing and very attentive" staff is "always full of Aloha spirit." More importantly, travelers say they're "always on time," with "convenient schedules and full-service meals for economy class."

items.title: Alaska Airlines
items.caption: "Superior service and quality!" Alaska Airlines received accolades from travelers with regard to service, food, and in-flight entertainment. "Alaska has stepped it up and is the primary carrier I choose when traveling for business or pleasure!" "Creature comforts like legroom in economy" mean there's "never a disappointment experience from this brand."

items.title: Singapore Airlines business class seats on the A340-500
items.caption: Business class seats on Singapore's A340-500 planes, which fly the longest route in the world.

items.title: Cathay Pacific
items.caption: Cathay Pacific's service is "unforgettable," says one reader. "Every crew member was so nice and caring." Ideal for business travel with in Asia, the "cabins are comfortable," but "there are no entertainment options or excellent food options to help you get through the long flight."

items.title: Korean Air
items.caption: "Too many great experiences with the cabin crews to mention!" The "wonderful, nice, caring service" is just one amenity on Korean Air—other flyers love the extras: "socks, toothbrushes, etc." "Their agents worked out a business-class travel problem directly and then called me when they had solved the problem," says one reader. "No stress on my part!"

items.title: Thai
items.caption: Thai's "friendly service matched with what seems like more personal space than most carriers" ranks them high on our readers' list. Before your flight relax in the "best lounges in the world." "Luxurious for the price," says a California reader. "You're treated like royalty."

items.title: Asiana Airlines
items.caption: "Every airline should be run like Asiana," raves one traveler. The airline's first-class OZ suites shown here include individual 32" HD displays and two-door seats. Asiana is "consistently good in food service and quality of flight attendants." On a long-haul flight, "their lay-flat seats were exceptionally comfortable." "I will bend over backwards to fly Asiana, even if the cost is a bit higher upon occasion."

items.title: Virgin Atlantic
items.caption: "Upper Class on Virgin Atlantic is about as fun as it gets at 35,000 feet," says one Massachusetts-based reader. Other travelers rave about this "very cool" airline's "fantastic" lounges, "friendly and efficient" staff, and "premium curbside check-in" at London's Heathrow Airport.

items.title: Swiss
items.caption: This "great airline to travel overseas on" has "exceptional service" and "great meals." Guests love the personal touches like wine, chocolate, and ice cream, but warn that "the food is not as good as, say, Air France." "The airport in Zurich is great."

items.title: Scandinavian Airlines
items.caption: Premium class on Scandinavian Airlines "can't be beat." Scandinavian receives accolades for "reliable" service, "very good premium-class lounges," and "fully reclining leather seats in business class." Customer service can be "hit or miss."

items.title: Turkish Airlines
items.caption: Our readers say this carrier is "one of the best," with "friendly cabin crews," "surprisingly fresh" food, and "wonderful service on-board." The "modern" fleet is "well-maintained". "It's what flying used to be like."

items.title: KLM
items.caption: With "very good service" and "great food on board," our readers find that KLM is a "good value for your money." "On the long flights, the stewardess are really on their toes," but "the lounges are a bit poor."

items.title: Etihad
items.caption: Etihad Airways Pearl Business Class (a [highly ranked airline on our poll](http://www.cntraveler.com/travel-tips/business-travel/polls/2012/best-business-travel-hotels-airlines)) boasts stylish seats that double as massage chairs.

items.title: Emirates
items.caption: One reader says, Emirates is "the best in the world. Period," while another likens it flying privately. The "wonderful" cabin crews make for "a great experience." "The quality of materials used in the first class suites "are exceptional." "Luxury at the highest level."

items.title: El Al
items.caption: Business class on El Al is "outstanding." Flyers are happy with the airline's "full and attentive service by staff who learned names and needs during one flight." One traveler warns, "they insisted on serving food at 2 or 3 a.m. Eastern Time, when we wanted to sleep."

items.title: South African Airways
items.caption:
The service and food is "excellent" on South African Airways, but premium class is a must, as readers say economy seats are "very tight and small." "South African Airways' level of service blows me away every time!"




 




**More from the Business Travel Awards:**




[Best Business Hotels in the U.S.](/travel-tips/business-travel/polls/2013/photos-best-business-travel-hotels-united-states)




[Best Busines Hotels in the World](/travel-tips/business-travel/polls/2013/photos-best-business-travel-hotels-in-the-world)

featureContentItems.socialTitle: The Best Airlines for Business Travelers

fields.caption: Ranked the best in ticketing, Web site, cabin comfort, service, entertainment, and food/beverage, it's not surprise that Virgin America is the domestic business traveler's top choice. One reader was "pleasantly surprised" by the airline's "new planes and the gracious service." "Flight attendants are nice and they cater to every clientele," says another.
fields.title: Virgin America

featureContentItems.hed: What a Billion Kayak Searches Reveal About the Way We'll Travel in 2015
featureContentItems.dek: Travel search site Kayak has turned more than a billion queries in 2014 into its first-ever Travel Hacker 2015 Guide, a report full of advice on where to go and how to get there this year.
featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/53dab561dcd5888e145c7093]|||
You'll want to go here.
|||





But why let Kayak have all the fun? We went one further, analyzing [their analysis](http://www.kayak.com/travelhacker) to make these predictions that should help you travel smarter—and save money—in 2015.

__Deals will determine destinations__

Travelers suddenly fell in love with Milan in 2014, Kayak said, with the city's share of click traffic growing by an almost unbelievable 105 percent year over year. Airfares, though, have fallen an average of 13 percent, leading Kayak to declare the city the number one deal destination for 2015. (The October 2013 launch of [Emirates service from New York’s John F. Kennedy International to Milan](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-04-09/emirates-airlines-launches-new-york-milan-service-october-040913) no doubt helped keep prices low.) With the Italian city hosting the World Expo from May through October, look for it to attract even more travelers this year. In addition to Milan, Hyderabad, Toronto, and Savannah appeared both on Kayak’s list of trending places *and* its list of best deal destinations. In general, travelers should monitor new airline routes as a source for deals on airfare. One good place to keep track of new options is [Airfarewatchdog](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2014-08-18/airfarewatchdog-com-s-tips-on-getting-the-best-airfare-deals).

__The ingredients will be local, the diners not so much__

Five of Kayak's [top ten trending destinations](http://www.kayak.com/travelhacker/trending)—Portland (third), Toronto (sixth), Savannah (seventh), Nashville (eighth), and Montreal (tenth)—are top North American cities for food. Joining a wealth of homegrown talent, established superstar chefs have expanded their empires to most of those cities in recent years as well, with David Chang now overseeing five Momofuku restaurants in Toronto, Hugh Acheson launching The Florence in Savannah, and Sean Brock bringing Husk to Nashville. As Americans' obsession with food continues to grow, so too will this trend. Keep tabs on emerging culinary destinations and make your travel plans—and restaurant reservations—*before* that up-and-coming chef ends up drawing national attention as a finalist on “Top Chef."

__The best time to buy airfare to Europe is yesterday__

Kayak suggests booking flights to Europe *six months* in advance to get the lowest airfare, a considerable change from [their advice last year](https://www.kayak.com/news/2014-kayak-travel-guide-everything-need-know-save/) to book only eight to ten weeks in advance. [As *Condé Nast Traveler* reported last week](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-01-29/airfares-arent-actually-dropping-heres-why), a strong dollar is making European travel more desirable for Americans—at least once they get there. With airfares to Europe likely as high this summer as they were last year, deals, particularly at the last minute, will be scarce. If you do feel the sudden need to flee the United States, head to the Caribbean instead of Europe: You'll find the best prices just two to four weeks in advance, according to Kayak.

__The most popular destinations in 2015 will be the most popular destinations of 2014 (and of 2013 and of 2012 and...)__

You can probably guess the ten most popular domestic destinations of the year: New York, Las Vegas, Los Angeles, Chicago, San Francisco, Orlando, Denver, Washington D.C., Seattle, and Boston. Kayak’s findings here are nearly identical to [every](http://www.hotel-price-index.com/2013/fall/american-travel-habits/top-locations-for-americans.html) [other](http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/travel/destinations/2007-07-27-most-visited-US-cities-forbes_N.htm)  [recent list](http://consumertraveler.com/today/forbes-lists-top-10-most-visited-u-s-cities/) of the most popular places to go. One way to find a deal in these perennial favorites? Average airfares to most of these cities spike in the summer months, so simply visit in at a different time of year.

__And airfare to those popular destinations will rise in July__

The most expensive month to fly to nine of Kayak's ten most popular cities was July. (The lone exception was Orlando, where December sees the highest fares.) If you’re flying to one of those cities this summer, Kayak's data suggests that June or August will see lower ticket prices.

__Beachgoers will keep it boring__

Interest in beach destinations this year will be as predictable as the rise and fall of the tide. Grenada, [Kayak’s top trending beach destination](http://www.kayak.com/travelhacker/beach/saint-lucia), saw a respectable increase in click share of 31 percent. Other "trending" destinations saw little change, though. Searches for Saint Lucia were up just eight percent; Saint Martin saw interest gain only three points. In other words, beach bums are not changing it up when it comes to where they relax.

__This summer will be the best time to visit Rio de Janeiro__

Rio de Janeiro saw the second greatest increase in interest from travelers compared to the previous year, up 49 percent. Related: from June 15 to July 13, 2014, it hosted seven World Cup matches, including the thrilling final. (The median airfare cost to Rio de Janeiro during June and July—typically the city’s offseason—was 28 percent higher than in May and August.) Expect a similar surge in interest and cost in August 2016 when the city hosts the Summer Olympics. If you are more interested in the city itself than a sporting event, this summer should make for a great opportunity to see [the very best of Rio](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-02-25/photos-rio-de-janeiro).

fields.name: Zach Everson
fields.shortBio: Zach Everson is a Washington, D.C.-based freelance writer, focusing on travel and food.
fields.bio:
Zach Everson is a Washington, D.C.-based freelance writer, focusing on travel and food. He has contributed to *The Wall Street Journal*, Air Canada's *enRoute*, *USA Today* and Eater. When traveling he's usually looking for Caravaggios, bourbon-based cocktails, and restaurants with
cheese carts.

featureContentItems.body:
[#image: /photos/53daa87f6dec627b149f9971]||||||

** You can't leave Tokyo without eating…**



 Soba (buckwheat noodles). In fact, you'll have a tough time leaving Japan without eating it at least once. Order a tempura lunch set (and you will, every day), and your tray comes piled high with cold, snappy noodles. Tokyo is sweltering and humid come summer, but a plate of chilled soba, often served with ice cubes mixed in, is the next best thing to climbing into the ice cream freezer at 7-Eleven.







**How to eat it**: Do not wear a white shirt. Your soba will be delivered to the table on a _zaru_ (bamboo tray), often with _nori_ (dried seaweed) sprinkled on top. Next to it will be a small cup of _tsuyu_ (a cold broth made from dried bonito flakes and soy sauce), an empty cup, a saucer with wasabi, and finely chopped _negi_ (scallion). Mix the tsuyu, wasabi, and negi in the cup; if you aren't used to spicy, go easy on the wasabi. If you're congested, it will clear you right up. Deftly use your chopsticks to pick up some soba noodles and then dip—don’t drown—your soba in the tsuyu. Lean over, open wide, and slurp heartily.







When you’ve nearly finished your soba, the waitstaff will bring over what looks like a lacquer teapot. It’s actually water from the pot in which the noodles where cooked. Hardcore soba lovers will pour it into their remaining tsuyu and drink it like soup.





[#image: /photos/53daa87fdcd5888e145c34a9]||||||

**How to order**: Like so many Japanese foods, this one is easy to order because its English name is Japanese. The menu will likely be in Japanese. Soba is often served as part of set meals, but if you want to order it a la carte, ask for "_zaru soba, onegai shimasu_" (“cold soba, please”). As soba broth is fish based, strict vegetarians will want to substitute soy sauce. Don't complicate things by trying to pantomime swapping soba broth for soy sauce, though; the soy sauce will already be on the table.







**How to pay**: The bill will be set discretely on your table after your order is relayed to the kitchen, but in the world's most polite country, this is in no way an attempt to rush you out of the restaurant. When you're ready to leave, just go to the cashier.







**Do you tip?** Tipping is not customary in Japan. If you leave money on the table, the waitstaff will try to give it back to you. Your polite thank you's throughout the meal are enough.



**Etiquette tip**: Leaning over your bowl and slurping the soba noisily is perfectly acceptable. You should inhale with gusto to cool down the noodles on their way from the plate to your mouth. Try not to cut the noodles with your teeth, and be careful not to let them slip from your mouth and splash back into the bowl. Do not douse your entire tray of soba with soy sauce; this is what the empty cup is for.











**More travel etiquette**:



[The One Dish You Should Never Order in Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/05/the-best-food-in-rome)







[What Not to Do in Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/12/what-not-to-do-in-las-vegas)



[What Not to Do in New York City](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/new-york/2013/12/what-not-to-do-nyc-travel)



_Sophie Friedman is a manager with [Context Travel walking tours](http://www.cntraveler.com/travel-tips/travel-specialists/paul-bennett), a company chosen as one of [Condé Nast Traveler's top travel specialists](http://www.cntraveler.com/travel-tips/travel-specialists)._
featureContentItems.dek: The one dish you should try in Tokyo. Plus: how to eat it, how to order, how to pay, and some useful dos and don’ts while visiting Japan’s biggest city.
